texts.definition: The goal of forming a spatial, temporal, or logical arrangement of game elements.
markups: <style="Definition">The goal of forming a spatial, temporal, or logical arrangement of game elements.</style>

Many games make use of game elements and have their spatial position or relation to each other as part of the game state. This sets up for having <style="CurrentLink">Configuration</style> goals, goals whose criteria for success are met by placing game elements in a certain <style="CurrentLink">Configuration</style>. Similarly, games that distinguish gameplay into discrete time units can have <style="CurrentLink">Configuration</style> goals consisting of performing actions according to a specific temporal <style="CurrentLink">Configuration</style>. A third alternate can be based on logical arrangements.

The card game <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Illuminati">Illuminati</link></style> uses <style="CurrentLink">Configuration</style> for control groups, which can be spatially arranged to draw benefit of similarities in alignment and maximize the use of control arrows. A more abstract example is <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Poker">Poker</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Texas%20Hold'em">Texas Hold'em</link></style>, where winning rounds consists of having the rarest set of a set of predetermined <style="CurrentLink">Configurations</style>.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Zendo">Zendo</link></style> is an abstract game where the winning condition is to guess a <style="CurrentLink">Configuration</style> decided by a player.

The design of <style="CurrentLink">Configuration</style> goals depend on which game elements should form the <style="CurrentLink">Configuration</style>, what spatial relations they should form, and what should happen when one fails or succeeds with the goal. Specific ways of creating <style="CurrentLink">Configuration</style> include <style="Link"><link="alignment">Alignment</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="enclosure">Enclosure</link></style>. The latter is less specific on the exact spatial arrangement and other <style="CurrentLink">Configuration</style> goals that need little or no spatial arrangement include <style="Link"><link="collections">Collections</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="combos">Combos</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Connection">Connection</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="rhythm-based-actions">Rhythm-Based Actions</link></style> can be used to make the <style="CurrentLink">Configuration</style> completely or much more focused on temporal <style="CurrentLink">Configuration</style> than spatial.

In some cases the challenge with <style="CurrentLink">Configuration</style> is simply placing the game elements, and this can be difficult due to the actions of others, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Imperfect%20Information">Imperfect Information</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Timing">Timing</link></style> requirements. In other cases the challenge can have more to do with <style="Link"><link="puzzle-solving">Puzzle Solving</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">Configuration</style> can easily be designed to support or break <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Symmetry">Symmetry</link></style> regarding the placement of game elements in a game.

A typical effect of succeeding with <style="CurrentLink">Configuration</style> goals in the <style="Link"><link="capture">Capture</link></style> of some game elements. This means that <style="CurrentLink">Configuration</style> goals are often motivated by <style="Link"><link="gain-ownership">Gain Ownership</link></style> goals. While this can cause <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Game%20Element%20Removal">Game Element Removal</link></style> of captured game elements, the game elements used to create the <style="CurrentLink">Configuration</style> can also be removed (or become stuck) and this <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Game%20Element%20Removal">Game Element Removal</link></style> can stop the goal from being completed several times.

<style="CurrentLink">Configuration</style> goals can be made so they are mutually exclusive — they are <style="Link"><link="incompatible-goals">Incompatible Goals</link></style> — by requiring the use of the same game elements when the game elements can't be reused. This makes these goals into a <style="Link"><link="selectable-set-goals">Selectable Set of Goals</link></style>.

Given that <style="CurrentLink">Configuration</style> uses spatial relations, they often offer <style="Link"><link="hovering-closures">Hovering Closures</link></style> to players that are beginning to near the completion of the <style="CurrentLink">Configuration</style>.
